tweets.text:
The UK has made a breakthrough in using science to tackle #coronavirus.  

Scientists can now use sewage to detect local outbreaks, even when people don't show symptoms.  

Find out more: https://t.co/JEJxbjIMR0 

#CovidSewageTesting @DHSCgovuk @EnvAgency https://t.co/vW5ratcTmN

We had reports of a swan stuck in Stallingtons Clyce near Combwich, the Parrett Field Team have attended site on the high tide and I can confirm the Swan is now free. @EnvAgencySW https://t.co/AQEEE7Lod8

Our new river site from the air, new habitats establishing & public access track nearly complete. A fantastic community effort at our @EPIC_Sompting project. Cleaner water and inspired community thanks to @HeritageFundL_S  @EnvAgencySE  @SussexGiving @SomptingDowns https://t.co/i6ukX73EzA

tweets.text:
Our scientists have made a breakthrough in supporting the UK‚Äôs response to #coronavirus.

We can now use sewage samples provided by water companies to detect local outbreaks, even when people don‚Äôt show symptoms.

Read more: https://t.co/VlvDhIA8I9

#CovidSewageTesting #TeamEA https://t.co/rhsdlZLGYE
@EnvAgency @EnvAgencyMids This isn't news. Countries in Europe have already established this. But as usual the UK are 10 steps behind.
@EnvAgency Yes and the water companies extract water from the rivers for domestic use after being treated.
@EnvAgency Does this mean its now in our rivers following the overflows from sewage treatment centres after heavy rainfall? What impact does this have on wildlife that use the rivers?

On #WorldOysterDay we are excited to announce we‚Äôll be delivering the new #WildOysters project locally in Tyne & Wear alongside @GWKNE Thanks to players of @Postcodelottery @OfficialZSL @Bluemarinef @Britishmarine who‚Äôve been awarded ¬£1.18m to recover native UK oyster populations https://t.co/Yu5qf1VXDP
